subject: AP Eagers (APE AT) plans to divest Klosters Motor Group in an effort to receive regulatory approval for merger with Automotive Holdings (AHG AT)
Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) Prelim. Q2 oper. profit fell 56% to KRW 6.5tln vs. Exp. KRW 6.0tln, rev. KRW 56.0tln vs. Exp. KRW 54.5tln, says Q2 oper. profit includes gains in display business
Shell (RDSA LN) has entered the retail power market in Japan
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Australia’s parliament passed the AUD 158bln tax package which will include an immediate AUD 15bln of tax cuts
content:
AUSTRALIA

Aristocrat (ALL AT) - Co. is suing rival Ainsworth Game Technology as it alleges that the latter stole the designs to one of its most successful slot machines. (SMH)

Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA AT) - Co. can earn nearly twice as much in interest income than its peers by being the slowest to pass on the latest interest rate reduction. (The Australian)

OceanaGold (OGC AT) - Co. files application for injunction to ensure continued operations at its Didipio mine in Philippines. (Newswires)

SpeedCast International (SDA AT) - Co. clarifies that it was one of the awardees of a US government contract and not the sole awardee. (Newswires)

Vicinity Centres (VCX AT) - Chairman-elect Peter Kahan takes leave of absence due to a health condition. (Newswires)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT) - Co. received interim authorization from Australia’s competition regulator to cooperate with Virgin Atlantic on flights between Australia and UK and Ireland via Hong Kong, LA and other future mutual connecting points. (Newswires)

Tax cuts - Australia’s parliament passed the AUD 158bln tax package which will include an immediate AUD 15bln of tax cuts for Australians. (The Australian)

 

JAPAN

ABC-MART (2670 JT) - Co. Q1 net JPY 9.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 9.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Aeon Mall (8905 JT) - Co. Q1 net JPY 8.0bln vs. Prev. JPY 7.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

McDonald’s Holdings Japan (2702 JT) - Co. June same store sales rose 6.3% Y/Y. (Newswires)

ROUND ONE (4680 JT) - Co. June same store sales rose 8.8%. (Newswires)

Seven & I Holdings (3382 JT) - Co. Q1 net JPY 52.1bln vs. Prev. JPY 42.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Toyota Tsusho (8015 JT) - Co. acquired a 10% stake in Powerhive. (Newswires)

Insurers - Japan FSA are reportedly considering tougher rules for life insurance companies. (Newswires)

Other News - Japanese PM Abe says to implement a macro policy approach if the global economic situation deteriorates. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Earnings - Samsung Electronics and LG Electronics are expected to announce Q2 results today. (Newswires)

Other News - South Korea Finance Minister Hong is expected to meet with the heads of the Chaebols. In other news, the government will come up with measures to deal with a looming shorter workweek at smaller firms according to the Finance Minister. (Newswires/Yonhap)

subject: China is said to ask certain trusts to limit financing related to the property sector
Croatia Central Bank Governor says country may adopt EUR as early as January 2023
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASES CALENDAR NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include Australian AiG Performance of Construction Index, Japanese Household Spending
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese Commerce Ministry said US-China trade teams are communicating and existing tariffs will have to be removed if US and China could reach a trade deal. (Newswires)

China’s Global Times Editor tweeted that China will fulfil its commitments once China and the US reach a deal and that the US shouldn’t set unfair conditions to prevent China breaking promises as Beijing will certainly reject those conditions. (Twitter)

US is to open a trade dispute at WTO against India in response to steel and aluminium tariffs. (Newswires)

Moody's affirmed China's A1 rating; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Johnson vowed to make Britain the greatest place on Earth as he said he will unite the country by delivering Brexit. In other news, Johnson suggested he could maintain lavish spending promises even if in the event that a no-deal Brexit wiped out the scope for extra borrowing by instead using the GBP 38bln “divorce settlement” payment with the EU. (Telegraph/Guardian)

UK Justice Secretary Gauke said he thinks the House of Commons will ‘find mechanisms’ to prevent the UK leaving EU without a deal and criticised Boris Johnson’s ‘do or die’ pledge. (Independent)

UK opposition labour party leader Corbyn has been urged by one of the MPs within the party to consider if he is the ideal person to lead the party after it experienced its worst ever rating in the polls. (Independent)

ECB’s de Guindos (Neutral) said we still need to enhance the counter-cyclical use of macroprudential instruments and that we need to develop, as well as deploy if necessary macro-prudential instruments for non-banks. De Guindos also commented that the Euro area’s ongoing economic recovery faces renewed global headwinds that are weighing on the economic outlook and noted factors such as trade uncertainties, EM vulnerabilities and Brexit which make the economic environment more challenging, while he suggested that the ECB’s accommodative monetary policy is necessary for inflation to remain on a sustained path towards levels that are below, but close to 2% over the medium term. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iran summoned the UK ambassador in Tehran after British Royal Marines seized a Panamanian-flagged tanker suspected of smuggling 2mln bbls of Iranian oil to Syria. (Newswires)

Iran said it is determined to further scale back on its commitments to the 2015 Nuclear Deal from July 7th. (Newswires) 

 

US

US was closed for Independence Day holiday.

subject: ASIA-PAC SERVICE IS NOW LIVE FOR TODAY'S SESSION
RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 4th July 2019: Markets uneventful amid holiday closures ahead of NFP
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • REAR VIEW: Thin trade amid market closures; US & China confirm restart of trade talks; Dovish comments from ECB’s Rehn.
  • COMING UP: Data; Germany Industrial Orders, US NFP, Unemployment Rate, Average Earnings, Canada Employment Change, Unemployment Rate, Ivey PMI, Speakers; BoJ’s Mayayoshi, ECB’s de Guindos, Coeure.

 

* US NONFARM PAYROLLS PREVIEW: The Street expects 160k payrolls to be added, rebounding from the disappointing 75k seen in May. Fed’s Powell suggested in his recent press conference that the central bank looks at the three-month trend, rather than a single print, and if the headline was realised, it would only be a touch above the three-month average rate at 155k. The pace of wage growth is seen accelerating vs May levels, while there will also be attention on the U6 underemployment rate, which fell to a cyclical low in May, amid a stable participation rate, which is seen as a positive. The data will be a key part of the FOMC’s case on whether it chooses to cut rates or stand pat on policy at the July policy meeting. The data will be released at 1330 BST/0830 EDT on 5 July 2019. To download the report, please click here.

* CHINA: NEC Director Kudlow said trade talks with China will continue in person in coming week. Both sides are in the process of scheduling a call, that is due to take place next week, between USTR Lighthizer, Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, and China Vice Premier Liu He. The timing of the call is yet to be confirmed. Elsewhere, MOFCOM’s Gao welcomed the US decision at the G20 not to put new tariffs on Chinese goods, but again reiterated that the removal of existing tariffs was essential for any trade deal. Kudlow said that the US has already been accommodative, and will not lift tariffs during the talks, adding that the US hopes China “will toe its end by purchasing a good many of American imports.” Separately, China’s Foreign Ministry reiterated that China will not engage in currency devaluation. Elsewhere, Moody's affirmed China’s A1 rating, outlook stable.

* ECB: ECB’s Vice President de Guindos noted that the euro area’s ongoing economic recovery faces renewed global headwinds that are weighing on the economic outlook. Moreover, uncertainties related to the rising threat of trade protectionism, vulnerabilities in emerging markets, and geopolitical factors, including those related to Brexit, make the economic environment more challenging. In this environment, said de Guindos, continued accommodative monetary policy is necessary for inflation to remain on a sustained path towards levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term. ECB’s Rehn was dovish in his remarks on Thursday, arguing that further monetary stimulus was required until there was an improvement in the bloc’s economic and inflation prospects. Rehn also said that the slowdown was no longer temporary, and that the ECB should be preparing for a stronger and more prolonged slowdown. He added that inflation expectations are a concern as market-based gauges are too low. Regarding a policy response, Rehn suggested that the ECB could change forward guidance, cut deposit rate, or even resume QE if needed before adding that there is flexibility to QE limits.

* ECB QE: Elsewhere, the speed at which Italian yields have fallen this week has left some analysts in awe. BTPs have benefited from dovish ECB speak, and the prospect of a dovish Lagarde at the helm of the central bank, as well as the EU opting not to open up EDP on Italy over high debt levels. This all comes amid the backdrop of a challenging economic environment, data shows. With the market front-running potential ECB QE, some have noted that if the central bank were to enact the policy, they’d be buying bonds at expensive rates. Accordingly, some are reasoning that the central bank will need to move further out along the yield curve in any future operations (assuming they target government bonds, and not, say, corporate bonds), since scarcity concerns will become a factor.

* IRAN: British forces seized an oil tanker off the coast of Gibraltar, on suspicion that the vessel could be carrying Iranian oil to Syria, in violation of European and US sanctions on the country. Iran responded angrily to the seizure, calling it illegal. Analysts now note the risk of a possible Iranian retaliation in the Strait of Hormuz. Separately, Iran doubled down on contentious comments made by President Rouhani on Wednesday, where he promised the country would increase uranium enrichment levels from 7th July, so long as the remaining signatories of the 2015 nuclear deal fail to fulfil their promises. However, an Iranian intelligence minister suggested that there was scope for talks between the US and Iran if the former was to lift sanctions on Supreme Leader Khamenei.

* CRUDE: The energy complex had a relatively tame day of trade amid thin volumes, being lightly subdued, but rangebound, at the time of writing. The usual demand/supply factors kept the market in a limbo, where bears are running off a slowing global economy as well as Wednesday’s more bearish than expected EIA release, and bulls are digesting extended OPEC+ cuts and a geopolitical risk premium. Due to the US holidays Baker Hughes reported its US rig count early this week on Wednesday, which showed oil rigs down 5 at 788, nat gas rigs up 1 at 174, leaving total rigs down 4 at 967.

* FX WRAP: Thin ranges characterised most FX majors, with US players on holiday. USD held onto Wednesday’s gains, while EUR has remained below 1.13 vs the buck, with dovish comments from ECB’s Rehn doing little to help the single currency. Meanwhile, GBP was uninspired, continuing to languish under 1.2600 after the run of dismal UK PMIs, and downbeat/dovish remarks from BoE Governor Carney earlier in the week. Safe havens were little moved; JPY and CHF consolidating around 107.75 and 0.9850 respectively vs the greenback. Antipodeans were slightly more active; NZD was under pressure after less encouraging comments from China regarding conditions for trade talks with the US (specifically, that existing tariffs need to be lifted for a deal). AUD held onto recent gains, which saw the AUDUSD move back above 0.70, breaching its 100dma to the upside. EMFX edged higher, as risk appetite remained positive; BRL was the outperformer as confidence grew that the special committee will vote on the pension reform bill today, which would increase the likelihood that the bill will be brought to the Lower House before the 19 July congressional recess. Analysts note that downside risks to BRL remain should pension reform bill fail to reach the lower house by this date. TRY also advanced, with USDTRY back down through 5.60 and eyeing key chart support in the form of the 200 DMA and a Fib (5.5857 and 5.5756), with traders pointing to capital inflows and investor appetite for Turkey’s 5-year bond as supplementary to the rally. ZAR was also on the front foot, USDZAR tested beneath the 14.0000 level, assisted by the bullish impetus gleaned via news that the SA Government is contemplating even more aid for Eskom, though has moved back above the 14.00 figure as Europe leaves for the day. RUB was unfazed by dovish comments from central bank chief Nabiullina, who suggested a 50bps cut could be on the cards at this month’s policy meeting.

* USD: After President Trump once again bemoaned the strength of the USD, desks are analysing how the President could achieve his apparent weak dollar objectives. UBS notes that USD strength, while antagonised by the Fed recently, is more a function of better relative growth expectations between the US vs the rest of the world. UBS explores what the US could do to weaken the buck, and reason that: 1) The threat of new tariffs is likely to aggravate USD strength due to its slowing of global growth; 2) FX intervention is unlikely as it runs contrary to the consistent US preference of not manipulating FX as well as the G20 consensus, however the more the USD strengthens the more this becomes a risk. 3) Recent Fed dovishness has seen some weakness in USD, ultimately UBS suggests that USD strength is more about global growth than the Fed. 4) Reaching a trade deal may be the best way to weaken the dollar, but it won’t happen right away, and UBS says that would need markets to price in more optimistic growth and policy outcomes in China and Europe.

* EUR: As ECB policymakers make more dovish noises, and the prospect of a dovish Christine Lagarde heading the ECB after Draghi’s departure, analysts have noted that implied volatility levels have been declining: for instance, the 1-year vol fell beneath 6.0 on Wednesday for the first time since 2007.

* AUD: Aussie retail sales bounced back, but still missed expectations, data overnight showed. Analysts note that Q2 retail sales data is now tracking around 0.5% Q/Q, easing from the 0.7% pace seen in Q1. Combined with the weak auto sales, indicators of consumption look weak in Q2, and augur poorly for Q2 GDP. Nevertheless, shorts continued to cover, while exporter demand was also cited for the AUD taking out its 100dma at 0.7033, and technicians are now looking for a test of the 200dma at 0.7098. One of the reasons for the Aussie strength, despite the dovish RBA, is the tax cuts implemented by the government, which some desks have said could be the equivalent of 50bps of cuts from the RBA – these cuts, it is said, take the pressure off the central bank to fire additional rate cuts. However, given the RBA monitors the Aussie (indeed, remarks from Governor Lowe recently highlight that it is monitored as part of its monetary policy transmission), the AUD strength may embolden the central bank to fire more rate cuts in order to manage upside appreciation.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 4th July 2019: Markets uneventful amid holiday closures ahead of NFP
content:

subject: Deutsche Post (DPW GY) are set to raise their standard postage price for major customers by 1.6% from 2020
US is to open a trade dispute at WTO against India in response to steel and aluminium tariffs, according to a WTO filing

ECB’s Rehn says further monetary stimulus is now needed until there is an improvement in economic and inflation prospects, if the central bank is to meet its mandate. Says slowdown is no longer temporary
content:
• Says slowdown is no longer temporary, and ECB should prepare for for a stronger and prolonged slodown
  • Inflation expectations are a concern, market based gauges are too low
  • ECB can change forward guidance, cut deposit rate, or even resume QE if needed
  • Adds there is flexibility to QE limits
  • Via Boersen Zeitung

subject: Major FX option expiries for today's NY cut
Russian Central Bank Governor Nabiullina says may consider cutting rates by 50bps in July
RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Bond bulls celebrate July 4th in the only way they know - 4th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

European indices are little changed this morning [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.1%] as the region mimics the performance in Asia, which ultimately failed on materialise on optimism seen on Wall St where the SPX briefly surpassed the 3000 mark. It's worth noting that volumes are tepid amid US' absence from the market due to the Independence Day holiday. This morning's notable movers include Persimmon (-0.4%) after a earnings update in which H1 revenue printed below the prior. The Verdi union reached a deal with German banking sector to include overall pay hikes of 4% until the end of 2021; German banking names such as Commerzbank (-0.8%) under some mild pressure this morning which may be stemming from this agreement alongside a downgrade at JP Morgan. Separately,  Osram Licht (+2.1%) is closer to the top of the Stoxx 600 following on from confirmation of reception towards Bain-Carlyle’s EUR 35.00 a share bid. Finally, the FTSE MIB (+0.5%) is marginally outperforming its peers as yesterday's confirmation that EDP procedures will not be instigated on Italy continues to generate strength in the Italian banking sector.

FX

DXY - The Dollar is relatively firm overall, as the index holds above key chart support within a tight 96.798-656 range in quiet US Independence Day trade and with several large option expiries keeping certain Usd/major pairs in check. However, the Greenback is markedly outperforming the Kiwi and Gold in contrast to heavy losses against some EM currencies, like the Turkish Lira and SA Rand.

NZD/CAD/AUD - All weaker vs their US peer, and the Kiwi especially after failing to maintain 0.6700+ status in wake of less encouraging Chinese comments on conditions for trade talks with the US (specifically that existing tariffs need to be lifted for a deal). Conversely, the Aussie has retained the 0.7000 handle and 1.0500 vs its Antipodean rival even though retail sales were a tad softer than forecast overnight and barrier defences in Aud/Usd at 0.7050 were not breached. Meanwhile, the Loonie continues to benefit from yesterday’s unexpected Canadian trade surplus and has only eased marginally from 1.3055 on the back of a downturn in oil prices.

GBP/EUR/CHF/JPY - Very little deviation vs the Usd as Cable consolidates between 1.2569-91 having lost grip of 1.2700 earlier this week during the run of dismal UK PMIs, and BoE Governor Carney’s somewhat downbeat/dovish remarks (that actually could be construed optimistic vs IHS/Markit predicting a 0.1% Q2 contraction rather than considerably weak growth). Elsewhere, the single currency is equally ensconced below a big figure amidst even more EGB yield compression and also engulfed in more hefty expiries with 1.6 bn at 1.1265, 1.3 bn from 1.1275-80, 1.8 bn at 1.1290 and 1 bn at 1.1315 vs 1.1278-95 parameters thus far. The Franc has largely shrugged off Swiss CPI, as the y/y rate stayed well below target, with Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf idling in 0.9857-69 and 1.1121-38 bands respectively, while the Yen is even more lethargic or lacklustre within 107.72-84 and like the Euro is also conscious of expiry interest close by (1.6 bn from 107.70 to 107.75).

EM - The Rand is just eclipsing the Lira in terms of relative strength vs the Buck, as Usd/Zar breaks through the 14.0000 level and gathers technical momentum to compound bullish impetus gleaned via news that the SA Government is contemplating more aid for Eskom. Meanwhile, capital inflows and voracious investor appetite for Turkey’s 5 year bond has supplemented the recovery rally, with Usd/Try down through 5.6000 and eyeing key chart support in the form of the 200 DMA and a Fib (5.5857 and 5.5756).

FIXED INCOME

EU debt may be left to their own devices and forced to go it alone given the absence of US participants, but it has not taken long for buyers to return and push benchmarks to fresh record highs, in most if not all cases. Bunds have now hurdled 174.00 to trade at 174.04 and accordingly the equivalent 10 year yield dipped under the ECB depo rate, while Gilts have erased all and more of their early Liffe losses to post a fresh contract high as well at 132.38. In terms of latest catalysts, nothing obvious or apparent, but French and Spanish bonds did seem to derive impetus after issuance. Elsewhere, only a grinding bid and marginal flattening in US Treasuries given July 4th constraints, but in the current fixed friendly or even frenzied environment catch up gains would hardly be a surprise, pending pre-NFP positioning for Friday.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures remain on the backfoot this morning in the fallout from the OPEC+ deal in which a “sell the fact” scenario prompted downside whilst upside is capped amid the EIA report yesterday which showed a narrower-than-forecast drawdown in crude stockpiles and an uptick in US production. Newsflow has been light for the complex thus far, although there were reports of a supertanker being seized by a detachment of Royal Marines and Gibraltarian authorities as it was suspected of carrying oil to Syria, which breaches EU sanctions against Assad’s regime. WTI remains below the USD 57/bbl level while its Brent counterpart hovers under USD 63.50/bbl. Elsewhere, Gold remains lacklustre as the yellow metal consolidates post-rally and remains north of USD 1400/oz, with volumes on the lighter side amid the US Independence Day holiday. Meanwhile, copper prices are subdued as LME inventories ticked higher, albeit downside in the red metal is somewhat capped by US-Sino trade optimism. Finally, Iron ore prices fell over 3% as the base metal consolidates from the recent back-to-back record setting rally.

subject: Fixed Income: bulls back for more after brief interlude
content: EU debt may be left to their own devices and forced to go it alone given the absence of US participants, but it has not taken long for buyers to return and push benchmarks to fresh record highs, in most if not all cases. Bunds have now hurdled 174.00 to trade at 174.04 and accordingly the equivalent 10 year yield dipped under the ECB depo rate, while Gilts have erased all and more of their early Liffe losses to post a fresh contract high as well at 132.38. In terms of latest catalysts, nothing obvious or apparent, but French and Spanish bonds did seem to derive impetus after issuance. Elsewhere, only a grinding bid and marginal flattening in US Treasuries given July 4th constraints, but in the current fixed friendly or even frenzied environment catch up gains would hardly be a surprise, pending pre-NFP positioning for Friday.

subject: Iraq oil minister says Iraq is to export crude to Oman, and are to build storage facilities in both countries; also reached agreement to import oil products from Iran
FX Morning Colour: Kiwi flags, while Lira and Rand fly
content:
DXY 

The Dollar is relatively firm overall, as the index holds above key chart support within a tight 96.798-656 range in quiet US Independence Day trade and with several large option expiries keeping certain Usd/major pairs in check. However, the Greenback is markedly outperforming the Kiwi and Gold in contrast to heavy losses against some EM currencies, like the Turkish Lira and SA Rand.

NZD/CAD/AUD 

All weaker vs their US peer, and the Kiwi especially after failing to maintain 0.6700+ status in wake of less encouraging Chinese comments on conditions for trade talks with the US (specifically that existing tariffs need to be lifted for a deal). Conversely, the Aussie has retained the 0.7000 handle and 1.0500 vs its Antipodean rival even though retail sales were a tad softer than forecast overnight and barrier defences in Aud/Usd at 0.7050 were not breached. Meanwhile, the Loonie continues to benefit from yesterday’s unexpected Canadian trade surplus and has only eased marginally from 1.3055 on the back of a downturn in oil prices.

GBP/EUR/CHF/JPY

Very little deviation vs the Usd as Cable consolidates between 1.2569-91 having lost grip of 1.2700 earlier this week during the run of dismal UK PMIs, and BoE Governor Carney’s somewhat downbeat/dovish remarks (that actually could be construed optimistic vs IHS/Markit predicting a 0.1% Q2 contraction rather than considerably weak growth). Elsewhere, the single currency is equally ensconced below a big figure amidst even more EGB yield compression and also engulfed in more hefty expiries with 1.6 bn at 1.1265, 1.3 bn from 1.1275-80, 1.8 bn at 1.1290 and 1 bn at 1.1315 vs 1.1278-95 parameters thus far. The Franc has largely shrugged off Swiss CPI, as the y/y rate stayed well below target, with Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf idling in 0.9857-69 and 1.1121-38 bands respectively, while the Yen is even more lethargic or lacklustre within 107.72-84 and like the Euro is also conscious of expiry interest close by (1.6 bn from 107.70 to 107.75).

EM

The Rand is just eclipsing the Lira in terms of relative strength vs the Buck, as Usd/Zar breaks through the 14.0000 level and gathers technical momentum to compound bullish impetus gleaned via news that the SA Government is contemplating more aid for Eskom. Meanwhile, capital inflows and voracious investor appetite for Turkey’s 5 year bond has supplemented the recovery rally, with Usd/Try down through 5.6000 and eyeing key chart support in the form of the 200 DMA and a Fib (5.5857 and 5.5756).

subject: Moody's affirms China's A1 rating, outlook stable

ECB’s de Guindos (Neutral) says we still need to enhance the counter-cyclical use of macroprudential instruments, and we need to develop and deploy if necessary macro-prudential instruments for non-banks
content:
• The euro area’s ongoing economic recovery faces renewed global headwinds that are weighing on the economic outlook. Uncertainties related to the rising threat of trade protectionism, vulnerabilities in emerging markets and geopolitical factors, including those related to Brexit, make the economic environment more challenging
  • In this environment, the ECB’s accommodative monetary policy is necessary for inflation to remain on a sustained path towards levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term
  • environment indicates that risks to economic growth are tilted to the downside.

subject: Iranian Intelligence Minister says US and Iran can talk if US lifts sanctions on Iranian Supreme Leader Khamenei
Gilts and Short Sterling futures unwind some recent/relative gains
content: Consolidation following yesterday’s ramp up and accelerated advances on the back of a 3rd UK PMI miss, as the 10 year bond pulls back further from new contract highs. Gilts kicked off Thursday’s session flat and high-ticked at 132.04 vs the previous 132.03 settlement, but quickly hit offers that pushed prices down to 131.86 and also appeared to weigh on Bunds that slipped to 173.61 before regrouping. Meanwhile, the 3 month strip is holding just off early lows of -0.5 to -2 ticks, albeit in light July 4th volumes and with little on the domestic docket to provide independent direction bar new passenger registrations.

subject: German Construction PMI (Jun) 50.0 (Prev. 51.4)
China Foreign Ministry reiterates that China will not engage in currency devaluation
Bunds: hovering just below midweek highs, as BTPs continue to fly
content: The 10 year German benchmark is respecting interim technical resistance around 173.76 in typically thin and lacklustre US holiday trade, but also acknowledging further outperformance in Italian bonds after the EU decreed that enough has been done by Rome on the fiscal front (for now at least) to avoid EDP action. Back to Bunds, 173.64-74 covers the range so far and turnover is less than 35k lots, but activity could pick up with the release of Eurozone retail sales and/or ECB speakers, as Lane and de Guindos are both slated. Note, however, the text from the former does not relate to monetary policy. Also ahead, heavy and multi-tranche debt sales from France and Spain that may warrant concession, and indeed seem to be capping OATs and Bonos now.

subject: Chinese Commerce Ministry says US-China trade teams are communicating and existing tariffs will have to be removed if US and China could reach a trade deal
analysis_details:
• This is in-fitting with comments from NEC Director Kudlow who stated that the next round of face-to-face talks between US and China will take place soon 
  • However Kudlow noted that the US will not lift existing tariffs during trade discussions, while he hopes that China keeps its commitments to make big purchases of US goods a
  • Reports also stated that the Trump administration is in the process of scheduling a call next week between US and China trade principles.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

4th July 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region benefitted from the mild tailwinds from US where stocks notched record levels and the E-Mini S&P briefly topped the historic 3000 level due to a jubilant tone heading into the Independence Day holiday and expectations of looser central bank policy. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were positive with Australia lifted after reports the government secured enough support to pass its AUD 158bln tax package and with the largest-weighted financials sector among the index frontrunners, while gains in Tokyo were limited by recent currency flows and amid an ongoing dispute with South Korea in which the latter warned of countermeasures for Japan’s export curbs. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were indecisive with the mainland subdued by another PBoC liquidity drain and as participants await the next developments in the US-China trade saga. In terms of the latest trade headlines, White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the next round of face-to-face talks between US and China will take place soon and that the US will not lift existing tariffs during trade discussions, while there were separate reports that China is considering US agricultural purchases as a show of goodwill but with the volume likely to be smaller than before.

FTSE 100

BT (BT/A LN) – UK Labour Party has played down the discussion that they were/are seeking to renationalise the Co.; which would have cost around GBP 30bln. (Newswires)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Co’s CEO has stated that planning for the new October 31st Brexit deadline has become more difficult due to the Co’s supply line being filled by stock for Christmas hence there would be less capacity for general stockpiling. (BBC)

Tesco (TSCO LN)/Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Walmart’s (WMT) stock market flotation of Asda is reportedly ‘two or three years away’, according to the Asda CEO. (Times)

Flutter Entertainment (FLTR LN) – Co’s shares moved higher yesterday, briefly posting gains of around 17%, following speculation that the Co. would be acquired if consolidation was to hit the gambling sector. (Telegraph/Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Banks – Verdi union has reached a deal with banking sector employers to include overall pay hikes of 4% until the end of 2021. (Newswires)

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – German Prosecutors are advancing an ongoing money laundering investigation into the Co.; which is to include the planning of raids on wealthy previous clients., according top sources. (Newswires)

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – Co’s supervisory board is reportedly meeting today in order to approve the partnership with Ford (F). (Handelsblatt)

Osram Licht (OSR GY) – Co’s supervisory board is meeting today in order to discuss takeover approaches from Bain & Carlyle., according to sources. (Newswires)

Wirecard (WDI GY) – Co. and CreditPilot have announced a strategic partnership in order to push forward provisioning of mobile and digital financial services to both network operators and retailers. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DEUTSCHE LUFTHANSA (LHA GY) DOWNGRADED TO SECTOR PERFORM FROM OUTPERFORM AT RBC

CAC

Valeo (FR FP) – Co. has received EUR 500mln worth of orders for their Lidar sensor. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

Fiat Chrysler (FCA IM) – Co. have named Grasso as COO of Maserati. (Newsires)

BROKER MOVES

SMI

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 4th July 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets traded mostly higher, benefitting from the mild tailwinds from US, E-Mini S&P briefly topped the 3000 level
  • White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the next round of US-China face-to-face talks will take place soon
  • In FX markets, the DXY was slightly softer, EUR/USD and GBP/USD were stuck below the 1.1300 and 1.2600 handles respectively
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ Retail Sales, ECB's Lane & de Guindos, supply from Spain and France, US Market Closure for Independence Day

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region benefitted from the mild tailwinds from US where stocks notched record levels and the E-Mini S&P briefly topped the historic 3000 level due to a jubilant tone heading into the Independence Day holiday and expectations of looser central bank policy. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were positive with Australia lifted after reports the government secured enough support to pass its AUD 158bln tax package and with the largest-weighted financials sector among the index frontrunners, while gains in Tokyo were limited by recent currency flows and amid an ongoing dispute with South Korea in which the latter warned of countermeasures for Japan’s export curbs. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were indecisive with the mainland subdued by another PBoC liquidity drain and as participants await the next developments in the US-China trade saga. In terms of the latest trade headlines, White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the next round of face-to-face talks between US and China will take place soon and that the US will not lift existing tariffs during trade discussions, while there were separate reports that China is considering US agricultural purchases as a show of goodwill but with the volume likely to be smaller than before. Finally, 10yr JGBs were uneventful as they took a breather from recent gains and with demand also dampened by mixed 30yr auction results.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 30bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8705 (Prev. 6.8640)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the next round of face-to-face talks between US and China will take place soon and that the US will not lift existing tariffs during trade discussions, while he hopes that China keeps its commitments to make big purchases of US goods and there were also reports that the Trump administration is in the process of scheduling a call next week between US and China trade principles. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK Brexit Secretary Barclays said a no-deal could result to a recession and shortages, while he also noted that government departments have been told to step up no-deal preparations. (Sky News)

UK Foreign Minister and PM candidate Hunt warned that MPs may be forced to cancel their summer holidays to pass the necessary laws next month for a no-deal Brexit. (Telegraph)

 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was slightly softer with US participants away for 4th July celebrations and after the recent mixed bag of data including ADP National Employment which missed estimates ahead of Friday’s key US NFP jobs numbers. Nonetheless, its major counterparts across the pond have failed to take advantage of the softer greenback with EUR/USD and GBP/USD stuck within the prior day’s ranges below the 1.1300 and 1.2600 handles respectively. Elsewhere, CAD traded at its strongest against USD since November and antipodeans also remained afloat due to their high-beta characteristics, in which AUD/USD printed a 2-month high and with weaker than expected Retail Sales doing little to dent the currency’s recent swagger. USD/JPY and JPY crosses were mixed as price action largely exhibited a non-committal tone and due to a lack of volatility in their base currencies.

Australian Retail Sales MM (May) 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. -0.1%). (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful overnight due to the absence of US participants for Independence Day and the somewhat cautious optimism in the Asia-Pac region, with WTI crude futures slightly lower after failing to break through resistance at the USD 57.50/bbl level and following this week’s narrower than expected drawdown in EIA crude stockpiles. Elsewhere, gold prices flatlined due to a lack of catalysts and as the impact from the risk sentiment was counterbalanced by slight USD softness, while copper languished amid indecision in China and recent pullback in iron ore prices.

US Baker Hughes Rig Count: oil rigs fell by 5 to 788, Nat gas rigs rose by 1 to 174, total rigs fell by 4 to 963. (Newswires)

Iraqi fire crews put out a fire on a strategic oil pipeline south of Mosul (which links Kirkuk to Turkey's Ceyhan Port) according to a security source, while reports noted that the fire was started by six explosive devices. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump tweeted that Iran has just issued a new warning and suggested that Iran should be careful with the threats as “They can come back to bite you like nobody has been bitten before”. (Twitter)

North Korea mission to the UN accused the US of being hell-bent on hostile acts towards North Korea despite the US stating that it wants talks. (Yonhap)

 

US

The European fixed income environment was influential; EGB yields were lower, with Italian BTPs particularly standing out, as the 10-year rate differential vs Bunds declined to around 200bps, as Italian 10-year yields dropped by over 20bps. It was confirmed today that Italy will not face disciplinary procedures by the EU due to its high debt levels, which helped BTPs. EGB’s have also been very well supported by dovish ECB remarks, as well as the prospect of Christine Lagarde heading the central bank after Draghi’s departure. Treasury trade had a thin feel to it, ahead of the July 4th market holiday on Thursday; the curve bull-flattened, with yields falling across the curve, despite strength in equities. US 10-year yields made further ground under 2.00%, with the US curve seeing yields fall to two-and-a-half year lows. There was also some influence from US President Trump’s nomination of Christopher Waller and Judy Shelton to the Fed Board of Governors; both are considered dovish candidates. T-note futures finished electronic trade 3 ticks higher at 128.07+.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade mostly higher as the region gets a mild tailwind from the record-setting pre-4th July session on Wall St
content:
Asia equity markets mostly trade higher as the region benefits from the mild tailwinds from US where stocks notched record levels and the Emini S&P briefly topped the 3000 level amid a jubilant tone heading into the Independence Day holiday and expectations of looser central bank policy. ASX 200 (+0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) are positive with Australia lifted amid reports the government has secured enough support to pass its AUD 158bln tax package and with the largest-weighted financials sector among the index frontrunners, while gains in Tokyo have been limited by recent currency flows and amid ongoing dispute with South Korea in which the latter has warned of countermeasures for Japan’s export curbs. Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) are mixed with the mainland subdued by another PBoC liquidity drain and as participants anticipate the next developments in the US-China trade saga. In terms of the latest trade headlines, White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the next round of face-to-face talks between US and China will take place soon and that the US will not lift existing tariffs during trade discussions, while there were separate reports that China is considering US agricultural purchases as a show of goodwill but with the volume likely to be smaller than before.

In FX markets, the DXY is slightly softer with US participants away for 4th July celebrations and after the recent mixed bag of data including ADP National Employment which missed estimates ahead of Friday’s key US NFP jobs numbers. Nonetheless, its major counterparts across the pond have failed to take advantage of the softer greenback with EUR/USD and GBP/USD stuck within the prior day’s ranges below the 1.1300 and 1.2600 handles respectively. Elsewhere, CAD traded at its strongest against USD since November and antipodeans also remained afloat due to their high-beta characteristics, in which AUD/USD printed a 2-month high and with weaker than expected Retail Sales doing little to dent the currency’s recent swagger.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are uneventful as they take a breather from recent gains and with participants also sidelined ahead of a 30yr auction later.

content:
China Machinery Engineering Corp (1829 HK) - Co. signs USD 345mln contract in Laos. (Newswires)

Chinese Estate Holdings (127 HK) - Co. expects to realize around HKD 1.33bln loss on stake in Evergrande. (Newswires)

Dongfeng Motor (489 HK) - Co. plans to produce electric vehicles in Egypt. (Newswires)

Future Land Development Holdings (1030 HK) - Co. removed its Chairman with the official currently held in criminal custody for personal reasons. (Newswires)

Huawei - Vodafone began 5G service in the UK using Huawei equipment. (Xinhua)

Utilities - NDRC issued its final policy on gas connection fees in which it stated the profit margin of gas connection fees should be capped at 10% of costs. (Newswires)

Trade

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said the next round of face-to-face talks between US and China will take place soon and that the US will not lift existing tariffs during trade discussions, while he hopes that China keeps its commitments to make big purchases of US goods. (Newswires)

White House Trade Adviser Navarro stated that the US and China have a strong commitment to the resumption of talks. In related news, there were separate reports that China is considering the purchase of some US farm products in a show of goodwill but with the volume of purchases likely to be smaller than before. (Newswires)

A Chinese importer purchased around 40 tons of medium-grain rice from California-based Sun Valley Rice, which represent the first ever purchase of US rice by China. (Newswires)

subject: Credit Suisse notes that valuations on SoftBank (9984 JT) look excessive

PRE-MARKET TAIWAN AND SINGAPORE NEWS: China Steel Corp (2002 TT) which is facing potential tariffs of over 400% on Vietnamese steel exports, said it is looking into the matter and would react accordingly
content:
TAIWAN

China Steel Corp (2002 TT) - Co. which is facing potential tariffs of over 400% on Vietnamese steel exports, is said to be looking into the matter and would react accordingly. (Newswires)

Other News - Taiwan legislature is to review fund repatriation bill, while it passed a bill to reduce import duties on 15 agricultural and fishery products. (Newswires/Focus Taiwan)

 

SINGAPORE

UOL Group (UOL SP) - UOL-UIC tie up was the top bidder for the Clementi Ave 1 site. (Newswires)

Data Recap - Singapore Purchasing Managers Index (Jun) 49.6 vs. Exp. 49.8 (Prev. 49.9). (Newswires)

subject: Hong Kong Manufacturing PMI (Jun) 47.9 (Prev. 46.9)
Australia competition regulator ACCC launches lawsuit against Samsung Electronics (005930 KS) for misleading advertising
PBoC is expected to set USD/CNY mid-point at 6.8743, according to a major news wire estimate
Philippines Central Bank Governor Diokno says 2019 GDP is likely to be 6.0% vs. Prev. forecast 6%-7%

Asia equity markets begin positive following the gains on Wall St where stocks hit record highs amid a jubilant tone heading into Independence Day holidays and expectations of looser central bank policy
